item.description:
Stack high to win, stack wide to win, just don't let the stack of furniture fall!

The game is hanging in the balance...think you can stack one more table or one more chair without toppling the pile? Then grab a piece of furniture, and get ready to play! Players take turns stacking tables or chairs any way they can, until one of them topples the pile all over! Be careful because the entire game is a balancing act! The player with the fewest toppled furnishings at the end of the game is the winner or if you'd rather, be the one to finish stacking all your furnishings first!

Some may know the game Chairs... this is incredibly similar except you have both tables and chairs, not just chairs to work with! This variation of the game "Chairs" provides new surfaces & chair shapes to stack and balance. Think you can balance that round table on the square chair with holes in it? How about putting that 3-legged chair upside down on a short long coffee table piece.

Game comes with 3 different color tables and chairs of varying shapes and sizes. Add a new play element to your game night with the game, "Tables and Chairs"!

This hilarious card game combines creative, open-ended questions with all new cringeworthy photos featuring funny family portraits, unfortunate hairstyles, weddings, vacations and holidays throughout the year!

Your ridiculous answers guarantee memorable & awkward fun...and if you know your fellow players well enough and can impress them with your answers, you'll get the last laugh!

Game is completely customizable in regards to rules changes, additions, etc. For example, you could add a couple dice to randomize your question number, rather than "learning the questions and choosing favorites". Really, this open game allows for house rules and so forth. The options are endless and the game can be altered based on your groups play-style.

 Note* Dice and 'extras' do not come in this game, they are simply suggestions.




Before the game begins, determine what 'score' you're playing to. Might be 5, might be 10, might be 34! It's up to the group to determine how long they plan to play. (See below, how to win)

On your turn, draw a photo card and choose a number (or roll a die, if thats your thing, completely up to you!). That number correlates to a question to be answered about the photo selected. Maybe you have to come up with a caption for the photo or maybe you decide what the portrait is thinking. Format similar to Cards Against Humanity, best answer wins picture card which equals 1 point. Or maybe you want to play by coming up with alternative answers and the group determines who said what best. Winner of that round keeps picture card and scores a point. First person to win "X" number of cards is the winner.

GO MONSTERS!

Go Monsters! is a card/board game that uses the card mechanics of Go Fish but adds board game mechanics of grid movement, tactics decisions, strategic planning, along with smashing buildings and victory points.

Age: Above 5
Number of Players: 2 to 4
Game Time: 20 to 30 min

Components:
[52 cards] - on [6] 8.5x11 single sided PDF sheets - Monster Cards "Equal to a regular deck of cards"
[1] - 8.5 x 11 Double sided PDF sheet - Game boards
[4] - d6 dice [2 white - 2 yellow]
[16] - building counters - "or you can use cubes, dice, tokens"
[4] – Individually colored Monster figurers with base – [red, green, blue, and yellow]
[1] rule book

item.description:
You count yourself amongst the best murderers in Victorian England. You must dispatch of your opponents one-by-one using various methods of villainy and vileness, but, be careful, for your fellow compatriots of evil deeds also want you dead and The All Seeing Eye of the Law diligently looks into the ominous shadows of the night.

During game play, players play action cards from their hand in which they may either do the action on the card or sometimes attempt murder on their fellow players by rolling the die.

Superhero Ko! is a simultaneous action two, four, or six player game packed with Golden Era Comic Book Superheros. Duel your fellow players in dice rolling matches to win XP. Who will be the first to KO! another player and become the hero the people need?

In Take Out the Trash, you must decided whether to Trash, Recycle, or Reuse. And, sometimes you find a dead cat or even a dead man. This card game is a fast paced trick taking game where the person who takes out the trash the best wins.

In this trick taking games, players are dealt a hand with which they must bid on the left over cards. The winning bidder declares a trump and the play begins. Players may also attack each other with Do Not Trash cards and the player with the most points on won tricks wins the match.

A dead body has been found on board a ship, and all passengers seem to have an alibi. Luckily several professionals are on board willing to help, but can you trust them? By asking clever questions and using deductive reasoning, you just might manage to expose the missing alibi and identify the murderer.

Perfect Alibi is a classic deduction game in the tradition of Sleuth. However, Perfect Alibi has a shorter playing time, and unlike other deduction games some of the information you get might be false. Finding out who is lying to whom is therefore crucial, and you must take full advantage of the abilities of several available assistants to gain the information you need.

item.description:
Build me up! The Self-Esteem Game is a roll-and-move board game where players attempt to earn money by praising other players and building their self-esteem. Players roll a die to move on a track, landing on various letters along the way. When they land on a letter, they must use three (or four or five, depending on the level chosen) positive words describing the player to their left or right in sentences, within 30 seconds. If they are able to do so, they earn an amount of money that corresponds to the difficulty of the letter (for example Y and U earn $1000, A and S earn $300). One player is The Negotiator, a sort of gamemaster. Players who are unable to think of enough words can buy a word from the negotiator (who has a book of suggested words) for half the value of the letter space. The Negotiator also controls the money and the timer.

Players may not repeat words that have already been used. Other players may challenge a word used by a player as being incorrect or not positive. If the challenge is successful, the challenger gets double the value of the letter. If the challenge fails, the original player gets double value. The rules specify that a dictionary should be consulted by the Negotiator. There are also "self-esteem" space where players draw a card which describes an effect of high or low self-esteem. These cards either give extra money to the player or cause a penalty to be paid. If a player must pay a penalty and has too little money, he or she must get a loan from The Negotiator, which must be paid back plus 10% interest.

Game play continues for 30 minutes. At the end of the game, the player with the most money wins, and is awarded a Certificate of Merit.

Quick Draw is a card came designed for 2-4 players whereby each player takes on the role of a Gunfighter in the old west. Each player begins the game with 30 life points, you can use glass beads or pen and paper to keep track of the life points. You will need a standard pack of cards that have 2 jokers, and around 10-15 six sided dice (less depending on number of players).

The game is divided into turns with each turn being made up of 3 rounds; Quick Draw, Aim and Fire. At the start of a turn the players are dealt 10 cards and then 5 communal cards are played face up in the middle of the play area.

For each round the players must use three cards from their hand to make the best poker hand they can. They place each round of cards face down in front of them (3 stacks of 3 cards). The left stack are the cards used for the Quick Draw round, the middle stack is used for the Aim Round and the Right Stack is used for the Fire Round. The last remaining card is placed to the very right of the Fire Stack.

When all of the players have made their selection all of the stacks of cards and the remaining card are turned over, spread out and revealed for all to see, then each player places 2d6 on top of their remaining card.

Starting with the Quick Draw Round, the poker hands are compared, players call out their best hand in turn giving the other players the opportunity to challenge their call. Once all hands have been called, the highest scoring player performs the action from the table below using the quick draw column and cross referencing it with his poker hand, once his action has been completed the next highest highest player performs their action in the same way, this continues until all player have taken an action.

Play moves to the Aim round which is repeated exactly as with the quick draw round and then the Fire round is performed.

When the dice are rolled in the Fire Round, their result is deducted directly from the player to the left or right of the active player who may choose either one. If a player ends with a negative results, then they take the damage themselves. When instructed to add or deduct dice in the fire round, just add or deduct the dice as directed to or from the remaining card of the player.

Dino Hunt Game is a dinosaur-themed roll-and move game that comes packaged with a book and toy in Smart Kids Dino IQ by Priddy Books. Players roll a die to move their markers along a track. Some spaces move players forward or back or cause loss or gain of a turn. These spaces generally refer to a dinosaur, such as "Rammed by triceratops' horns--lose a turn." The first player to reach the end of the track wins.

It's the classic fast-dealing property trading game of Monopoly, now with multitudes of minions! Gru is back with another evil plan and it's up to you to collect Banana Bucks and own all of your favorite properties before he succeeds. Spin the Minion Spinner to move your minion around the board and wheel and deal to win the most mischievous Monopoly game ever!

This Despicable Me 2 version of Monopoly is mischievous property-trading fun! Buy and sell properties! Collect Banana Bucks! Includes exclusive minions! 50 minions to collect! (Each sold separately.)

Game includes 4 minion tokens, spinner pod with Nom Nom Tom minion, game track, game tray (plus 2 clips), 16 Cupcake tokens, 8 Ice-Cream Sundae tokens, 16 Property cards, 16 Chance cards, Banana Bucks and game guide.

Multiplay is a "multiplication learning game of luck and skill." It is played on a board numbered from 2 to 9 across the top and along one side, forming a grid. Chips showing all the multiplication products of the numbers on the grid are included. Each player takes an equal number of chips from a face-down pile and places them standing on edge, so they are visible to the owning player and hidden from other players. Leftover chips are placed on the correct squares of the board.

In turn, each player spins a spinner, looks at his or her chips, and places any chips corresponding to the number spun onto the grid. If the chip is placed incorrectly (i.e. not the product of the numbers in the row and column) the player must take the chip back and lose a turn. If the spinning player does not have the number spun, he passes to the player on his left, who may then play that number if possible. If not, play continues to pass to the left until a player can play the number. If no one has the chip, the first player to spin spins again until someone can play a number.

The first player to play all his or her tiles wins.

ManaSurge is a competitive magical card game in which dueling wizards fight for possession of the mystical World Crystal, a valued relic among magic users that grants immense power to whichever wizard wields it. You are one of the many wizards who have come to claim the stone, but gaining control of the stone won’t be an easy task.

This free-for-all magical showdown pits 2-6 wizards against each other over a series of rounds. Each round is a magical duel between all the wizards, which includes six different types of magic: Blades, Fireball, Frost Wave, Lightning, Quake and Metamagic. These magic types will aid wizards in their duel.

Players take turns casting an initial spell that will set the rule for the round, set the rank other players must beat, and earn them a potential Shard (VP). Players then take turns playing cards of equal or higher rank from their hands to the table; if they match the spell suit, they place a Shard on that card. The round ends when a player can no longer play a valid card from their hand. The player that could not play a card returns any Shards on their played cards back to the center, then takes card damage equal to the amount of Shards that are still on cards. All other players then take the Shards on cards they played to their Victory Pool. The player who played the last card gets a bonus Shard.

When a player takes damage, they draw cards from the deck equal to the amount of damage and place them face down in front of them. If they ever accumulate 5+ damage, they immediately discard their hand and a Shard, then take their damage cards in to their hand.

The game ends when one player has enough Shards. 15 in a two-player game, 12 for three or four players, and 10 for five or six.

item.description:
From the company web site...
Since its inception in 2003 Twenty/20 cricket has gained in popularity making it an important part of the modern game, batting, bowling & fielding techniques have become more evident in the longer versions of the game as more & more T20 games are played year on year.

Twenty20 cricket is currently the shortest version of the game with scores in excess of 200 possible on the (mainly) batsman friendly wickets used for this format of the game.

Twenty20 cricket emulates to reproduce the excitement & tension that draws such big crowds to the real thing, within this game are four batting grids for different types of wickets. Along with four batting & four bowling grades plus a few other charts that will enable the user to replay a full game in around 30-45 minutes when the rules have been mastered, this will ensure a statistically accurate scorecard with a wealth of stats (strike rates, economy rates etc.) and hopefully a nail-biting finish to boot.

Rating players is a simple task & although the grades are in themselves quite basic they will reproduce roughly what is achieved in real life (a T20 batsman's strike rate is regarded as a more valuable asset than his average and a bowlers economy is his main ˜weapon").

The game includes the following Ratings:

ICC World T20 (2014)

Friends Life domestic T20 (2013).

Big Bash league 2013-14

Indian Premier League 2014

Champions League 2013

Caribbean Premier League 2013

The game is played mainly with 2d6 and a d10, which is used occasionally. Batters score runs by rolling a die and moving up a grid, different ones are based on the condition of the wicket. Their starting point on the grid is based on their letter grade. Certain points of the grid will then reference the bowler's grade - you roll a d10 to determine if the batter is out or not.

Castle Builder is a card drafting game where the cards you select build a castle that will house Nobles, Knights, Servants, Princesses and even a King and Queen! There are 3 rounds of drafting where the cards get more valuable, but more expensive and your gold is dwindling. Fortunately each card you add to your castle has 3 attributes, Victory Points for winning, Defense to protect against other players attacks and Favor. Favor is added to your Victory Points at the end of the game, but in between rounds it can be traded in for more gold so you can afford the more expensive cards, but then gold is not worth any Victory Points. There are other ways to gain gold such as sending your knights on adventures or buying Vaults for the Nobles to store their wealth in.

Speaking of Nobles and Knights these can be added to your castle through adding specific cards and score addition points at the end of the game. The real prize is when you add the right rooms to gain the King or Queen!

However, your opponents will be attempting to ruin your prospects of success. They can pay to discard cards you need, throw waste into your castle preventing people from inhabiting it or just outright attacking you to steal Victory Points.

It is up to you to manage your gold, Nobles, Knights and Servants to build the most impressive castle and win the game!

Childbirth Trivia is a trivia game to test and teach knowledge about childbirth to expectant parents or health professionals. Players compete to answer questions in a number of categories. Players roll a die to determine which of six categories they will answer. Another player draws a card of the corresponding color and asks the question. If the question is answered correctly, the player rolls again and answers another question, continuing until an answer is wrong. Once a player answers questions in all six categories, he or she must answer one last question in a category chosen by the other players. A correct answer wins the game.

A longer version of the game requires players to progress through various levels. Some levels require answers in each category, some are free choice categories and others allow opponents to choose the categories.

Questions may be asked at level 1 (for the general public or expectant parents) or level 2, for health professionals or other childbirth professionals.

This game can also be played with a board from Trivial Pursuit or a similar game, substituting the Childbirth Trivia cards.

Flash Duel: Second Edition is a simple, fast card game that simulates sparring matches amongst Fantasy Strike characters. The fight takes place on an 18-space linear track, and it's all about striking from the right distance and getting to the right range. This edition contains 20 characters, each with their own special abilities, allowing for hundreds of different matchups.

There are seven different modes of play:

 Simple mode, for first time players
 Full mode, using the character abilities
 Custom Clockwork: build your own character!
 2v2 team battle
 Solo play, with 10 achievements to earn
 Raid on Deathstrike Dragon: 2, 3, or 4 players cooperate against a powerful 5th player controlling the Dragon
 Betrayal at Raid on Deathstrike Dragon: A more difficult raid where one player is secretly on the Dragon's side!




Changes to the Revised Second Edition:

--All game modes now use a 40 card deck, rather than different modes using 25, 40, and 50, and the game will come with 40 numbered cards rather than 50. In all modes other than the Dragon Raid, you start each round by shuffling the deck and setting aside 5 cards without looking at them. In 2v2, you reshuffle the discard pile twice when it runs out before reaching timout. In the Dragon Raid, you reshuffle it 1, 2, and 3 times for 2, 3, and 4 mortals, respectively. Overall, rounds last longer in all modes.

--Last-hits is no longer a mechanic in the game. At timeout, you just check who advanced farthest. This is simpler and turns out to have better dynamics by forcing action to take place during the actual gameplay part of the game.

--Whenever a round ends in a tie, now both sides get a win token.

--A new rulebook makes the game less mathy and more about improv and bluffing. Players don't know the exact contents of the deck anymore, so they can't compute things so completely. Also, players now draw more cards each round, so they have more chance to win before timeout.

Part of the Fantasy Strike universe.

item.description:
Description from the publisher:

Welcome to the realm of Rokugan: a land of samurai and mystics, mad dragons and divine beings — a land where honor is stronger than steel. Here, the clans serve the Emperor and engage in courtly deceptions and power plays, even as they wage war against each other and the evil forces that plague their realm. This is the world of Legend of the Five Rings!

Legend of the Five Rings: The Card Game is a Living Card Game set in the world of Rokugan, the original setting for the Legend of the Five Rings collectible card game. To play a Living Card Game, players create individual decks of cards from a base game with a fixed set of cards; they can then add supplemental card packs to this game world, with each pack also having a fixed set of cards, in order to vary their game experience.

While the connection of Legend of the Five Rings: The Card Game to Rokugan and the Colonies — as well as its pervasive themes of honor, nobility, magic, intrigue, duty, and warfare — should carry over from the original L5R CCG, Legend of the Five Rings: The Card Game is not compatible with that original game and will feature significant changes in the game mechanisms.

item.description:
Write down a secret word to do with a specific topic and use your imagination. During the game you will have to carry out 5 different tests: coincide with your teammates, try not to repeat the same as them, avoid secret words, discover secret topics and be the one to find the most words, all at blistering page.

In this word game a card theme is shown and then a dice is rolled to indicate the rule players have to follow this turn. Then they have 30 seconds to write 4 words that accomplish the rule. They will score one point for each right word. At the end of the game the player with the most points is the winner.

You can mime as many words of "subject", "action" or "object" as you like. Your teammates must guess them and make with them all the craziest sentence possible. But beware, if you risk too much and the time runs out, you will lose everything.

Playing by teams in your turn you have to roll the dice and take as many cards as it showed. Then, turn down the sand clock and you have to mime all the cards. When your mates guess them, they have to construct a sentence with all of them to win the cards. If done, you can choose to roll the dice again and take new cards but if your time ends before they get the words and the sentence, you will lose the cards and some of yours yet won. At the end of the game, team with most cards is the winner.

Tell an anecdote about the chosen topic and listen to those of your opponents. A secret card wil let you know whether you should tell the truth or lie. You must make everyone believe you, and use your wits to discover which of your opponents is lying.

Each player receives secretly a card that indicates if he has to say the truth or lying. Then, a theme card is showed and every player explains a personal history on the theme lying or telling the truth depending on his card. When finising all players can make questions to the others to guess if they're lying or not. Before that, they count up to three and everybody points the person who he thinks is the liar.

You get points discovering the liar and when anybody thinks that are you and it's not. Five cards are played and then the player with most points wins.

On the Top is a game that will test what you know about your teammates and your reaction speed. First is assigned a "nickname" to each player. Then each turn is read a card with a condition like "he has the longest tongue", "he has more brothers", "more holes in the belt" ... and everyone will have to draw who believe that meets at the same time you say his nickname in the game.

First player to guess who meets better the condition will win the card. Game finishes when anybody wins 5 cards.

Do you really know your friends? And your partner?

Fast Words is a very fast game to form words, where you have 8 letters and a theme, and have to decide a word that relates to the theme, using as many letters as possible and do it the first time.

A word about "something with a lot of hair" ... What you thought? Or another about something that "has holes."

A pile of theme cards is placed on the center of the table surrounded by 8 cards with one letter in each one. When showed the first theme card players have to find a word on the theme that have at least one of the showed letters. Who founds put his hand over the theme pile, say the word and takes all the letters contained in it. The rest of the players plays the same way until only one player has no said any word. Then, letters are replaced and a new theme is showed. Player with most cards at the end of the game is the winner.

A new and simplified version for the famous game Mouse Trap using the characters from Elefun & Friends.

The trap is built at the setup and, although different, has the same basic elements of the original.

You do not have to collect cheese anymore and the movement is determined by a spin wheel with three colors.

The board is smaller and composed by a path of colors where some of the spaces have also a boot indicating that the player may activate the trap and try do capture a mouse. The first player to capture a mouse wins the game.

Become a member of the Alliance of Hunters, travels the Invizmals world and capture the most powerful ones, train them and make them evolve to fight the X-Tractor commander ... but beware, the journey is full of dangers.

A game based on the Invizimal license from Sony where the players has to stop the invasion of their world capturing Invizimals and fighting with them again the X-Tractors using their power dice and cards. Combats can be made too using an specific App.

A Trivial-like game with 2.600 questions about all facts and history about the soccer team Real Madrid. Players advance along the board tracks by correctly answering questions to complete his collection of trophies.
Depending on the squares where his pawns land they have to answer questions about specifics themes like players, history or prizes. But they can also stole trophies to the other players quicking penalties or dueling with questions with them.

The players move their meeples on the yellow spaces from "Anfang" to "Ende" around the game board. Movement is determined by the black die. The only function of the three red dies is to roll a 13, wich grants the players some benefits. The red, green or black spaces above the yellow spaces, in combination with the result of the red dies, determine if the player loses or wins money.
Light of Dragons is a tactical dice and positioning game in which players battle in the role of ancient peoples who are trying to become ruler over warring lands.

item.description:
Crazy Therapy!! is a competitive card game in which two teams exchange in turns the roles of "patients" and "therapists".

Each team draws a card of the deck (48 cards total), which represents a "pathology" (a pattern behavior they have to perform in their "patients" turn)
There´s plenty of funny pathology types, like identity disorders where you have to "be" another specific player, behavior disorders, TICs, and much more madness!!

In the "therapist" turn, you have to ask the patients with questions whose answer should be YES or NO. When all the therapists have asked a question, they can try to make a diagnosis in the end of the turn in an attempt to win. There´s also two special clues in each card: "lamp" and "dartboard". The therapists can request the "lamp" clue at the beginning of their turn, but this has a penalty: they lose the entire turn and they are forced from this moment to reveal their own "dartboard" clue if they fail a diagnosis.

There´s also a special event called "Therapy" when a patient shouts "THERAPY!! and all the patients should switch seats randomly between themselves (note that lots of pathologies take into account some sort of "possitioning" pattern, so i.e.: if you have to act and answer like the person at your right, this changes your answers after a Therapy! because there´s another person at your right!), this event can happens when:

-The patient don´t know the answer of a question.
-The pathology says to do it or when it´s impossible to follow it´s indications.
-A patient fails to following the pattern or indication of the pathology (in which case, if you detect a teammate patient "fails", you should shout Therapy!!)

The goal is to discover the opponents pathology (the "pattern") before they discovers yours!

A fast and funny game that can join in the same table every profile of board game player!!
____________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________________

Crazy Therapy!! es un juego de cartas competitivo en el que dos equipos intercambian los roles de "pacientes" y "terapeutas".

Cada equipo roba una carta del mazo (hay 48 en total), que representa una "patología" (un patrón de comportamiento que tendrán que interpretar en su turno como "pacientes")
Hay muchos tipos de patologías divertidas, como trastornos de identidad donde tendréis que "suplantar" a otro jugador específico, trastornos de comportamiento, tics, ¡¡y muchas mas demencias!!

En el turno de "terapeutas", tendréis que preguntar a los pacientes con preguntas cuya respuesta deba ser SI o NO. Cuando todos los terapeutas han preguntado, pueden intentar hacer un diagnóstico al final del turno para intentar ganar. Hay también dos pistas especiales en cada carta: "bombilla" y "diana". Los terapeutas pueden solicitar la pista "bombilla" al inicio de su turno, pero esto tiene un precio: perderán automáticamente el turno y además, a partir de ese momento estarán obligados a revelar su propia pista "diana" al equipo rival si fallan un diagnóstico.

Hay también un caso especial llamado "Terapia" donde un paciente grita ¡¡TERAPIA!! y todos los pacientes deben intercambiarse aleatoriamente los asientos entre ellos mismos (ten en cuenta que muchas patologías juegan con algún factor de posicionamiento en su patrón, así que por ejemplo: si tienes que actuar y responder como la persona de tu derecha, ¡esto cambia tus respuestas tras una Terapia! ya que ahora habrá otra persona a tu derecha!), este evento ocurre cuando:

-El paciente desconoce la respuesta a una pregunta.
-Lo indica la patología o es imposible cumplir su directriz.
-El paciente falla al interpretar el patrón o la indicación de la patología (en cuyo caso, si detectas un compañero paciente "fallar" deberás gritar ¡Terapia!

¡El objetivo del juego es descifrar la patología rival (el patrón/funcionamiento) antes de que ellos descubran la vuestra!

¡¡Un juego rápido y divertido que unirá en la misma mesa a todos los perfiles de jugadores de mesa!!

name.value: Rugrats: Turn the House Upside Down

item.description:
The object of the game is to be the first player to explore and mess up the objects given to you at the beginning of the game.

In a two player game, each character must mess up 6 objects to win. In a three player game, 4 objects; and in a four player game, 3 objects.

To start, put together the 3D game board, put the neat sides of all the items into their respective slots on the game board. Put the Mom and Dad marker on the spot on the game board with the star. Select a Rugrat and place it in the playpen, then deal two cards to each player. The remaining cards form the draw deck.

On your turn, you roll the die.

If you roll a number:

- Move your Rugrat up to that number of spaces on the game board
- If you reach an object you have a card for place the card face up in front of you and flip the object to the messy side
- You do not have to land on the object by exact count
- If there's another Rugrat or Mom and Dad in your way, jump over that space (don't count it)

If you roll 'Draw':

Add a card from the draw pile to your hand.

If you roll 'Mom and Dad':

- Move Mom and Dad up to 6 spaces on the game board
- If Mom and Dad land on any Rugrat, send that Rugrat back to the playpen
- Mom and Dad can, like a Rugrat, ignore a Rugrat and not count a spot to travel farther on the board
- If Mom and Dad move onto a red dot space in front of one of the house items, they block any of the Rugrats from making a mess of that item until they are moved

From the back of the box:

All right, all you Rugrats, break out of the playpen. It’s time to turn the Pickles house upside down!

Race through the family’s kitchen, bathroom, living room… upstairs and downstairs on the 3-dimensional game board. And what do you do when you reach one of your objects? You turn it upside down!

Mom and Dad try to prevent the mess—but they can’t be everywhere at once. Sooner or later, you and the Rugrats turn the whole house upside down. What a mess you’ve made!

Het Koninkrijk Dominion ("The Kingdom of Dominion") is an introductory version of Dominion. It contains 16 kingdom cards, and there are only 8 copies of each cards, instead of 10. Most of the cards come from Dominion and Dominion: Intrigue, but there are also cards from the other sets.

This game is good to get to know Dominion and makes it easy to learn, especially for smaller children.

Het Koninkrijk Dominion does not contain reaction cards, duration cards, curses or other cards with a lot of rules or confrontation.

item.description:
Drink-a-palooza is a party game that takes many common popular drinking games and puts them in a structure of a roll-and-move board game. The game is played on a Monopoly-style board, with player pieces as small six-packs. Players roll a die to move around the edge, and the space that the player lands on directs the player what to do. Depending on where you land, you will either play a group game such as high/low (card game that involves everyone playing) OR there are twelve bottle spaces on the map. The bottle spaces cause the players to play a mini-games of beer pong (throw a ping pong ball into a cup), quarters (bounce a quarter into a cup), or flip cup (flip a cup from right side up to upside down). If you win the mini-game, you receive a small plastic bottle to go in your six-pack. First player to six bottles wins the game.

From the publisher:

Drink-a-palooza is the ultimate drinking board game that mixes everyone’s favorite college drinking games & packs them into one dynamic competition. Whether you prefer beer, spirits, soda or water; you will love playing these games! This game eliminates the need for a large Ping-Pong table & makes for the perfect housewarming gift. "Pre-game" with drinkapalooza or take it to your buddy’s keg party. Get the bachelor & bachelorette party started & throw a killer “after party”. Drink-a-palooza board game takes your favorite games and makes them a thousand times tastier.

item.description:
At the zoo are lots of animals to see, but after we see them once, will we find them again? Do we know where all the animals are hiding?

In Vier im Zoo, first the cards are laid out face up, then after all players have had a look at the cards, they are turned face down. Starting clockwise, each player takes a turn shaking the wooden disc inside the cover, then trying to find the corresponding animal card. Whoever is first to find four animals wins!

Space is a hard place and making a bit of scratch out here is even harder. Racing against fellow scavengers you must reach derelict ships and earn enough cash to buy your way out of this long, harsh and tedious life!

In Space Junkers, 2-4 players compete to grab fuel cells and spend them to reach derelict ships. Players roll dice and place them on fuel cell cards in order to outbid or block their opponents. Valuable fuel cells are used to buy derelict ships, earning victory points. The first to 12 points has collected enough from the derelict ships to move on to a better life. May the best salvage company win!

An adult board game.

The game of impossible choices and hilarious results. 3 famous names; 3 hard choices. Who to Snog. Who to Marry. Who to Shove. Drew Barrymore, Lucy Liu, Cameron Diaz, Enrique Iglesias, Antonio Banderas, Ricky Martin. Decisions, decisions! It's hard enough trying to decide what you'd do, let alone guess what everyone else is thinking. there are hot seat question cards for you to make up your own choices - family, friends, work mates, ex-boyfriends, ex-girlfriends, or, if you're really daring, your fellow players! The winner is the first to get to the finish (and is still talking to their partner!)

Have you ever looked up in the sky at all the stars, at the marvel of the Universe and felt a curious nerve inside wanting to travel to these stars, see the planets, and maybe find life? Expedition Zetta includes 3D-models of spaceships, gorgeous art, and a modular game system. In this game for 1-5 players, you and your fellow travelers each represent a country in a maiden voyage of the first starship to ever use a newly developed warp drive. The goal is to brave the unknown and collect discoveries in four different star systems. Though you may have to cooperate, one player will bring special fame and fortune to their home country. Will it be you?

In Expedition Zetta, you start the game by recruiting 1-4 crew members, then you will:


 Discover strange planetary systems, randomly generated each game based on the latest scientific data
 Find exotic new substances never before seen
 Develop exo-products that can advance human technology
 Gain new knowledge
 Encounter new forms of life or ruins and settlements of vanished, ancient alien civilizations with their promise of both danger and discovery
 Perhaps encounter another star-faring civilization whose members might even become part of your crew, making it not only international but interstellar
 See crew interactions that can lead to romance or intrigue, which can either help or hinder you


Every game plays differently! Each game includes four planetary systems. After warping together to a distant star, you travel with your crew individually between planets, searching for life and substances or trying to construct exo-products. If the life you find is intelligent, you may even interact with it. The discoveries are your main source of Fame.

The revolutionary Zetta Planetary System Generator, used in the advanced game, can generate as many different star systems in the game as there are in the known universe, each with its own unique characteristics and its own name. Thus, no two voyages to the stars will ever be the same! During the warp stage in the advanced game, you interact with the other players' crew members to gain advantages. Romance or intrigue may occur, with varying effects.

Apart from the gameplay experience, a journey with Expedition Zetta will give you knowledge about stars and planets, along with memories of when you for instance managed to extract gems from a gaseous giant in a triple star system, from when you found life in a lenticular galaxy or when you managed to produce time crystals near a super-hot supergiant O-star.

Expedition Zetta has a basic version that is great for the whole family.

 Want a quick game? Use the Quick rules!
 Want to add special adventures and encounters to your mission? Play adding one or several of the specialized rule modules!
 Want to play solo? There are two different solitaire variants.
 Playing for the first time? Use the play-and-learn tutorial.

item.description: Sheep Happens is a look into a ridiculous world where incredibly dumb sheep will have to figure out how to save themselves from the angriest, craziest, and most bizarre goats you've ever seen. A card game where you need to steal and imprison enemy players sheep, using powerful and dumb goats to attack them, while you defend yours. Defend from your opponents attacks placing fences in front of your sheep, using traps or scrolls from your hand and If you have any goat cards in your hand, attack your opponents in order to capture as many sheep as you can. Each captured sheep is worth one point, and the first player to reach seven, five or three points, wins the game.

The game consists of 2 items: poles and balls.The balls’ holes are the connection point of the items. Each of the 2 players picks a colour with its 44 items: 12 balls and 32 poles.

RULES FOR 2 PLAYERS

The game starts with the player who selects the white items. The player can choose to start with a pole or a ball. Each player plays their turn using only one item at a time: a pole or a ball.
Every piece played must be linked to the pieces played beforehand. As the poles are inserted in the ball holes a three dimensional figure will begin to form. Once an item is placed, no changes or modification can be made.

AIM OF THE GAME
A player wins the game if during their turn they manage to:
• Insert 3 poles more than their opponent in any played ball
or
• place in a straight line 4 balls of the same colour.

Given that each ball has 6 holes and each player wins by placing 3 poles of the same colour more than their opponent the winning possibilities are 3-0 or 4-1. The players build up a three-dimensional network where there are different diagonals (2D or 3D) that allow placing 4 balls of the same colour in line. The game is considered a draw when both players use up their pieces and no player can place 3 poles more than their opponent into a ball or 4 balls of the same colour in line. Positioning and placing the pieces of the game in a clever way is part of the winning strategy.

In order to create a solid structure and to minimise the risk of the structure breaking during the game, we suggest placing the poles firmly in the ball holes.

RULES FOR 4 PLAYERS
The same rules for 2 players apply. Pairs of 2 players start the game with 44 elements each, playing on alternate turns and interposing one player of each couple.

item.description: 3 Monkeys is a party game in which player must make static mime of various emotions - fear, hunger, ambition, greed, despair... - with their face. Every round, a player must mime three emotions - one with hand over ears, one with hand over eyes, and the last one with hands over mouth. It's not always that easy...

Rocket Shogi is a stand-alone small board (5x7 grid, with 8 pieces per player) Shogi variant. Unusually, it uses all standard Shogi piece types except for pawns.

It can be played using standard Shogi pieces.

It is also included as a second independent game (using its own board and pieces) with Simple Shogi in a combined package sold under the title "Simple Shogi".

item.description:
Tricky Pirates is a trick-taking, area control game. Players play cards in tricks that allow them to move their own pirate loaded ships, stab opposing pirates, or sink opposing ships. Pirates in ships fight for control over treasure kept on five islands. But watch out, pirate ships work on wind power and the wind will not always blow your way.

At the beginning of the game, the treasure on the islands is bonuses and play effects. But very quickly it becomes doubloons. The player that controls three islands worth of doubloons at the end of a trick wins.

Welcome to Banana Republic, a political unstable country where the economy is controlled by political and business elites. You are one of the elite of this nation, and your objective is to stash enough money in an offshore trust fund that you can retire comfortably. Invest your income in stocks, properties and bonds, then exert influence on the government to manipulate the economy for your personal gain. Orchestrate the downfall of other elites by destroying their personal life through car accidents, expensive divorces, and shotgun babies. Do you have what it takes to survive in this cutthroat world of money mania?

Wongamania: Banana Economy is an economic and modern finance board game that reflects the complexity of modern investment portfolio management by incorporating multiple asset classes that behave differently under different economic situations. Deviating from the traditional auction mechanisms used by most stock-trading board games, Wongamania: Banana Economy uses a combination of resource management, environment manipulation, and take-that mechanisms to reflect the brutal competition and uncertainty of the modern global financial markets. Players have to manage a portfolio of stocks, properties and bonds, and assess the risk-reward of holding them in different allocations. Players are also able to influence the economic environment by manipulating it to either benefit their personal investment allocation or to wreck havoc against other players who are using a different asset allocation strategy. Players are also able to make use of their money for other purposes, such as sabotaging the personal lives of other players, hiring professionals to disrupt the strategy of other players and buying insurance to protect against sabotages. Whoever stashes enough money in a off-shore trust fund wins the game.

Wongamania: Banana Economy is a reimplementation of the 2014 game Wongamania (only available in SEA), and multiple changes have been made to cater better to the international audience.

In 2037, the first settlers arrived on Mars! The base camp was already settled and now, during the next fifty years, a group of very brave people from private space exploration companies are establishing a major colony ruled by a terrestrial organization, the D.O.M.E. (Department of Operations for Mars Exploration).

As a chief astronaut from a private space exploration company, you want to be a pioneer in developing the biggest, most advanced colony on Mars, achieving the D.O.M.E. mission goals as well as your company's hidden agenda. By bringing in and managing settlers, you can explore, mine, build, power, and upgrade buildings. You will lead the construction and assembly of greenhouse farms, water compounds, Oâ‚‚ factories, power generators, and mines. The goal of humanity on this new planet is to learn how to value water, air and the the things we need to live more than money — and in the end, become a self-sufficient colony independent of any terrestrial organization. Do you dare to take part in mankind's next biggest conquest?

On Mars is played in turns using different phases:


 Players decide which D.O.M.E. goals will be part of the game, how the new settlers from earth will be distributed through the different colonies, and which community buildings and materials Earth needs to authorize and provide.
 Players will have available to everyone a limited set of actions they can take in their turn and the raw materials sent from Earth.
 In turn order, players take one action, but they need to plan carefully; builds consume power and a second building may not be placed before a generator is upgraded.
 Last, all the Colony parameters are adjusted.


Actions may be to build buildings, rovers or ships; to produce; to buy or sell resources; to explore; and to research. Actions take the form of worker placement, cards in buildings, scientists tokens, or tech tiles. All actions have an energy cost, so upgrading the generators and the existing power grid is very important. At the same time, most of the buildings need ore to be built, plus energy, people, and Oâ‚‚ to run. Settlers need food, water, and shelter to be able to survive. Food, water, and Oâ‚‚ needs to be stored. If you can't store enough resources, the population will not grow...

item.description:
Space-themed, dexterity luck, skill, strategy game using dice, marbles and discs. Its bocci ball, bowling, shuffle board, craps, pool, and a little bit of monopoly.

Players send out their ships by flicking and rolling from cornered docks. The objective is to land on the positive spaces, ring bearers or the black hole with your disks. Watch out for negatives and the black hole with your marble and dice.

Defense is also allowed if you can hit your opponents ships with yours. Setting a round maximum, the player with highest points at the end of the set round wins. You can actually win by losing in this game. Simple to learn and competitive to play.

item.description:
Different preconditions and as many surprises and incidents enliven this race of wedding guests. While playing, you are exercised in knowledge and mastery of the most fundamental rules of the road.

Each player has a rental car. With it, he must transfer the members of a family to a wedding. Before picking up passengers, the driver must prove their condition by examination. Only then you can go pick up the various family members.

The driver must also buy a gift. When all requirements are exceeded, each driver must try to get the first to the wedding. But along the way not only must observe all traffic rules, but also be able to make money in various ways. Only when you have 100,000 in cash you can reach the finish line as winner.

In Frantic, you start with seven cards and try to get rid of your cards as quickly as possible. If a player has discarded all their cards, the remaining players count the points in their hand. When a player reaches the agreed maximum score, the player with the lowest score wins.

If you can't or don't want to play a card, you draw one from the deck. There are four colors with numbers from 1 to 9. You can either play color on color or number on number. Sounds boring so far, doesn't it? Well, that's why we have the special cards. For example, have someone draw four cards from the deck, or give a fellow player two cards out of your hand. And the fun part: You always get to choose who gets these cards!

But wait, there's more: We come to the black cards, also numbered from 1 to 9. You can play these only on a number, not on the same color, and every time a black card is played, it activates an event card. These event cards go from Friday, the Thirteenth — where nothing happens – to Tornado, where all hand cards get shuffled together and handed out again.

name.value: With All Due Respect: The Party Game

item.description:
With All Due Respect is a new light-hearted game about what you and your friends really think of each other!

With All Due Respect - The Party Game is an adult party game for 2+ people. Gameplay is incredibly simple and unique.

Before the game starts decide who is lucky enough to be on your VIP LIST. When a player is answering a "With All Due Respect" playing card they choose their answer from this list.

You can add other people who are not playing the game to the VIP LIST. Adding these other people will give you more names to choose from when answering questions.

On your turn: 
1.) Draw a playing card, choose any question from the card and read it out loud starting "With All Due Respect".
2.) You then secretly write down on your answer pad a name from the VIP LIST that you think is the best answer. 
3.) Now everyone else will use their 2 Poker Chips to guess which answer you selected.

As fun and ridiculous as it may seem, it gets even more hilarious. The questions alone will sprout hours of laughter and debate. But unlike any other party game their are Drawing Cards and Wild Cards to play.

You will have the opportunity to draw a person from the VIP LIST and everyone else will use their 2 Poker Chips to guess your drawing.

Playing With All Due Respect - The Party Game is like taking your basic adult party game and injecting some steroids into it!

The player with the most points after 12 rounds wins the game.

“Welcome to Rome” the eunich said as you enter the official's ante chamber, “We have been expecting you and have prepared the Senate for your arrival.” Lucius Quintellius will be here within the hour with your requested documents...

Patron is a card game where each player takes the role of a freedman, a class without oblique power, but very energetic and ambitious. You will seek to control the correct mix of Senators from various classes, affluent locations with vast prestige and resources and the laws of Rome itself.

Setup

Shuffle all the cards of Patron deck together and choose a starting player. Draw cards appropriate to the number of players, and choose one to play and discard the rest. In a 2 player game, draw three cards. In a 3 player game draw two cards. In a 4 or 5 player game draw two, but players also have the option of playing the top card of the discard pile instead of drawing.

Playing the Game

When playing a card, you must do that action stated on the card, but only if can: i.e. if a card requires you to sacrifice a Patrician and you don't have one, you may ignore the effect. In a 4 or 5 player game, do not mix sacrificed cards with the discard pile. A sacrificed personality is removed from the game.

Each player draws and plays in a clockwise fashion until there are no cards left to draw and the game is over. If there is only one card left the last player must play this card as their final card. Then each player tabulates their total.

Determining a Winner

The player with the most points at the very end of the game wins. Many cards are worth variable points based on the number of symbols, locations, agendas or personalities that player has.

name.value: Jenga: Transformers – Rise of the Fallen

item.description:
From Publisher:

Are you ready for a new twist on Jenga? Bring home the classic game of falling bricks coupled with elements from the blockbuster Transformers: Revenge of the Fallen movie. For ages 6 and up, this family game for two or more players allows you to take control of Cybertron-- or family game night-- with your robot-like brick-removal skill. The tiles feature Autobot or Decepticon faction logos and are made from a tasteful, black material. Build and battle with the Transformers Revenge of the Fallen Jenga Battle Game!

How to Play:

Divide up into two teams Autobots and Decepticons. The Decepticons go first. Teams alternate turns, rotating so that each player gets chance to play.

on you turn, remove one block. Then see if the block shows a symbol:

 if it does not show your TEAM´s symbol, stack the block on top of the tower
 if it shows your TEAM´s symbol, pass it to a player of your choice on the other team. this player must stack the block before the team takes its turn.




Winning:

If the tower falls over on your team´s turn, your TEAM LOSES. The other TEAM WIN!.

name.value: ApexWar: The Armageddon (The Height of Warfare)

item.description:
APEXWAR: The Armageddon
(The Height of Warfare)

A Game for Big Minds!
In the Era of a highly Militarized New World, Play Chess like a M.A.D. man and start Armageddon !!!

It's 2030 A.D. :
Advances in the developments of the FORD class and SHTORM class Aircraft Carriers and with the advent of the 6th Generation Multi-role Fighters, leads to a new balance of power between the adversarial spheres of influence.
Some are not happy with this new balance, whilst some are over-zealous with it.
Tension, Twilight, Point of no Return, Mutually-Assured-Destruction, and World War 3

You are Commander-in-Chief of a Super-Power Military Force about to clash with another.
- 1 Globe
- 2 Hemispheres
- 2 Commanders-in-chief
- 2 Super-Powers (Each spread across both hemispheres)
- 4 Navies (2 each)
- 4 Armies (2 each)
- 4 Air-Forces (2 each)
- Special-Forces Marines 
- The Secret-Service (including Double Agents) 
- Military Top-Brass; Generals, Admirals and Air-Marshals
- Strategic ICBM’s and Nuclear Deterrents
- Missile defense systems, Satellites & Radar
- Bunkers, Cities, Logistical & Economic Infrastructure including the 'Global Monetary Fund', bank rolling it all.
This is epic war on all fronts.
It's Armageddon!

ApexWar is a truly epic game in scope and in depth. A true union between strategic and tactical gaming.
An expansion on the ApexWar army and navy themes including other forces and a commander-in-chief, you control a super-power spanning two hemispheres.

In this epic struggle for supremacy, your primary mission is to protect the commander-in-chief piece from being captured at all costs to avoid losing the war and to win the war, you must capture the opposing commander-in-chief.
Your secondary mission is to protect your flag bearers and strategic facilities namely your admirals or capital ships, generals, air-marshals, satellites and radar from capture or destruction as they control your unit forces, whilst trying to capture and destroy the opposing commanders and facilities to significantly weaken their forces.
Everything else is canon-fodder, dedicated to upholding and achieving your primary and secondary missions.

The army and navy pieces all move correspondent to their representative standard chess character. Most of the other pieces also all move similar to standard chess characters but some of them incorporate modifications to their movements, capturing and abilities. Then their are the static pieces that do not move as the represent infrastructure, so they have to be defended.
Finally, the whole epic plays out within an economics frame, where you have to acquire control and protect resources like oil, steel and gold to boost your war efforts and also to protect your cities to keep up morale.

It's not easy being the President, Good Luck.

Cat and Medieval and Contemporary Household Themed. The cats are divided into royalty designations/strength ranking and are attempting to exert control over locations in a Kingdom i.e. a bedroom for the purposes of napping.

The gameplay consists of a drawing card then taking 1 or 2 actions of the following: placing cats in territories, placing Battle Cards of various types from the player's 4 card hand to give cats battle strength and scoring potential, battling opponent cats for control, and restoring cats after a battle. Drawing territories out of the deck and certain event cards add variety to gameplay/strategy.

The goal of the game is to have the most victory points at the end of the 3rd draw deck. the victory points are gained by dominating territory based on the cat's size, faction, and royal stack relative to opponents. A second way to earn victory points is to have a valid quirk or bonus VP stack by the game's end. There are penalties to VP for holding certain cards and for cats being defeated in battle.

In Re-Extinction, dinosaurs have been resurrected for battle. Armor your dinosaurs to defend them from environmental hazards like stale grandma smell and boiling rivers of taco meat. Make every other player's dino re-extinct and be the last surviving dinosaur!

From the publisher:
Bzzzz, bothersome flies are buzzing all around. Inviting landing pads are everywhere, but the flies only have eyes for the brown feasting pile of "fly candy". Only the player who plays his cards correctly can quickly move ahead with his flies! But beware! No one is safe from the fly swatter, and some flies may have to return to the starting point just before they reach their final destination.

User summary:
In Fly Feast, each player tries to move his four flies from the starting space to the destination. The players take turns. Each turn, they first draw a card. This triggers some effect, which may apply a permanent special effect to a space. After drawing the card, the may move one of their flies one or two spaces. The first player to reach the destination with all of his flies wins the game.

item.description:
Rogue Squad is a cooperative science fiction board game that combines fast-paced combat action with exciting strategic challenges.

In this compelling futuristic adventure, 1 to 4 players step into the boots of a misfit band of mercenaries who must battle their way through ever-increasing swarms of monstrous aliens.

Rogue Squad is an exciting turn-based game with easy-to-learn rules. Depending on the mission’s level of difficulty, one game lasts from 1 to 3 hours. A fully developed universe, intriguing characters, and story-based missions allow you to focus as much (or as little) on roleplaying as you like.

Rogue Squad at a Glance

• fast-paced combat action
• fully cooperative
• one-of-a-kind alien spawning mechanism
• unique combat system using custom dice
• no game master necessary – aliens are controlled by the game itself
• rich in variety: versatile elements can be combined in many ways (troopers, sidekicks, co-op robots, aliens, boss, non-player characters)
• add-ons change up gameplay even more
• mission-specific rules and special features make every gaming session fresh and fun
• troopers’ main weapons and skills can be upgraded
• large selection of weapons and combat equipment
• search, event, alien and alien overlord decks
• easy-to-learn rules
• can be played either as stand-alone scenarios or multi-game plot arc
• maverick (= skirmish) and expert modes offer truly grueling combat for especially ferocious fighters
• free mobile app for even more innovative gameplay options

item.description:
"Play as one of five factions, each with its own victory condition, representing heroes and villains in the Marvel Cinematic Universe."

The main board is for 3-5 players played out over a city map for sector control. A 2-player map is included for the Guardians of the Galaxy card game.

Go Nuts for Donuts is a fast-paced card game for the whole family with just a sprinkle of strategy. Outsmart your opponents and collect donuts hot out of the oven for points. But beware, if two players go after the same donut, then no one gets it!

In Go Nuts for Donuts, players lay out donuts from the deck equal to the amount of players plus one. Each player has a number card for each donut that is out. Players all pick a donut they want by placing one of their number cards face down on the table. Players simultaneously reveal their number. If two or more players have matching numbers, that donut is discarded and no one gets it. If you're the only player that bid for the donut, than you take it and place it face up in front of you. Collect sets, unique and powerful donuts, and pairs of donuts to maximize points.

link.value: Go Nuts for Donuts: Apple Fritter

item.description:
The Luzon Campaign, 1945 is a wargame, purpose-designed for solitaire play, which covers the fighting across the main Philippine island of Luzon early in 1945. You, as the single player, actively commands the invading US forces, while the rules direct you in the deployment of the defending Japanese. You win or lose via the seizure of (or failure to seize) key areas on the map. You are cast in the role of US Sixth Army commander Lt. Gen. Walter Krueger. In turn, you’re under considerable time pressure from theater commander Gen. Douglas MacArthur (portrayed passive-aggressively by the victory conditions and six-turn limit) to be finished with the major portion of the campaign no later than the end of March. That’s necessary to allow the redeployment of major aero-naval assets for the Iwo Jima and Okinawa battles.

World at War #59

Victory never tasted so sweet!
It’s a beautiful spring day, the flowers are in bloom and there is an epic battle waging beneath the petals.

Honey Wars is a card and dice game with a strong "Take That" mechanic. You and your fellow players control hives of bees, working to build your army while blocking your opponents’ efforts to do the same. Use cards to attack your opponents, defend your hives, harvest honey and WIN THE WAR!

A rather rare football simulation from Wilson Sports. Play happens through use of cards, dice, a gridiron board, and a wheel for offense and one for defense upon which players select their chosen plays and then compare results.

User note: I contacted Wilson Sports Equipment, and they at first told me that Wilson never made sports games, then, when I insisted that I had one in front of me, said that they had no knowledge of any such products.

Terra Incognita is a scenario based solitaire game about organizing an expedition and explore unknown lands in the heart of Africa at the end of the 19th century. Your goal is the accomplish the chosen sceanrio by organizing and leading your expedition. You have to prepare your expedition with crew members and items to survive in the wild territories of Africa and then face events and decide how to continue your journey to reach your goal and return to the civilization to acquire fame and glory!

The game use a tile reveal mechanism in a point-to-point system. You discover new tiles as you progress on the map. On each tile you will find mandatory or possible actions what you have to resolve with the help of your crew members, items and the use of six sided dices. Time has a fundamental role in the game as you has to track the time spent on expedition and provide supply for your memebers from time to time. Random events also occures what can effect your scenario and you have to react them.

From the publisher:

Pass the Grass is an interactive board game that borrows elements ranging from the innocent world of Milton Bradley to the psychedelic vibe of the Grateful Dead. Rolling both dice and joints, players make their way around the board in a quest for the perfect buzz while completing hilarious challenges and satisfying their lust for “munchies.” Pass the Grass can be played with 2 or more players but they must be 21 or over. Clearly, this is a game for adults (cough).

Take turns drawing cards (and puffs) and complete challenges to win. Includes: 1 game board, 2 dice, 6 game "tokens," 2 decks of cards, and a rule book.

GAME PLAY: Everybody puts $1 in the jackpot. There are two sets of cards, you roll dice and there are places on the board that tell you to do different things. You take a card, and each card will tell you to do something different. There are credit and pass cards. A credit card means you do what the card says, which could be anything from taking a hit off a joint, to eating some munchies, to telling an embarrassing story. If you take a pass card, you pass it to anybody and then they have to do it. If they choose not to, they’re out. If you land on the jackpot, you get all the money and everyone replenishes it with $1 each, but it can be more if players want. Players who choose not to ante up are out. Last player still playing wins the pot. (Everyone else wins a nice buzz.) For a shorter game, play ends when someone lands on the jackpot.

Players may substitute a shot of booze for a puff of pot.

This is a game on political conflict in the last years of Japanese Edo period (1856 to 1867). The basic game engine is based on Twilight Struggle.

Players control either pro-Tokugawa Shogunate or anti Shogunate (imperial) faction. Each turn players play historical event or common political operation cards. This mostly helps them to place their own influence points or remove the opponent's influence points. The difference of Influence points determines the control of hans (domains), and it also affects control of areas.
The winner is determined by victory points, mostly gained by area control.


Issue game of Game Journal #56

item.description:
Bone Head: the spooky little card game for 2-9 players.

The Bone Heads are on the hunt for roses!

Players take turns to add their Bone Heads to a forming chain by linking hands and avoiding other Bone Heads with the same colour top hat. If a player is unable to play a Bone Head they must collect another from the graveyard.

The first player to play all their Bone Heads successfully collects a rose from the graveyard or steals one from another Bone Head.

Domino+ mechanic with a spooky twist.

item.description:
Starting from the idea "A territory an action" to Isle at War I rebuilt the game by adding my ideas and other games trying to keep it simple and fun intact.

The variations are:

I added an action called "Alliances" in which you draw a card from the Allies that can make a additional action; 
I replaced the original map with a modular hexagons; 
You can play up to 4 players; 
The territory with the castle can produce 2 troops; 
The game lasts 10 rounds; 
The player with the most points in this way: 
1 point for a territory; 
3 points for the special territory; 
1 to 3 points for cards Allies; 
At the end of any turn, the player with more than half the territories may declare the end of the game.

Enjoy!

Alessandro

PROTECT THE GALAXY AND SHOW NO FEAR!

As a member of the Justice League, you are the last line of defense to protect billions of lives from the worst imaginable foes. Will you make the difference? Will you secure the safety of mankind?

With this BATMAN set for HERO DICE you join the Justice League as the Dark Knight.

Gather your friends around you, roll the dice and battle villains with cunning and deception.


Justice League: Hero Dice – Batman is a cooperative game. There are several sets available. Each set enables you to play one hero from the Justice League. Each set has material for one player. Multiple players can play, with a set for each player (and both can play Batman, or each a different character).

Each hero has its own set of dice, his own rules and his own arch enemies.

The aim of the game is to protect your hometown. The villians are attacking Gotham City, Metropolis or another city. Try to push them back.

Get bonus points for good teamwork. After the attack you can count your points and lick your wounds.

Justice League: Hero Dice is NOT a collectible game, but each set gives you new options.

item.description:
PROTECT THE GALAXY AND SHOW NO FEAR!

As a member of the Justice League, you are the last line of defense to protect billions of lives from the worst of horrible foes. Will you make the difference? Will you secure the safety of mankind?

With this SUPERMAN set for HERO DICE you join the Justice League as the Man of Steel.

Gather your friends around you, roll the dice and battle villains with your Super Strength.


Justice League: Hero Dice – Superman is a cooperative game. There are several sets available. Each set enables you to play one hero from the Justice League. Each set has material for one player. Multiple players can play, with a set for each player (and both can play Superman, or each a different character).

The aim of the game is to protect your hometown. The villians are attacking Gotham City, Metropolis or another city. Try to push them back.

Get bonuspoints for good teamwork. After the attack you can count your points and lick your wounds.

Justice League: Hero Dice is NOT a collectible game, but each set gives you new options.

Each player needs his own set to participate in Justice League: Hero Dice

item.description:
Join Mickey Mouse and friends on an exciting race through 12 exquisitely illustrated Disney realms, from Radiator Springs and Alice’s Wonderland to Peter Pan’s Never Land and Winnie the Pooh’s Hundred Acre Wood. Throughout the race, everyone searches for iconic Disney objects and gets a chance to say, “I found it!”

Set the clock to 1:00. Once the game starts the clock is ticking and players must work together to get to Cinderella’s castle before the clock strikes midnight. On your turn, spin the spinner and either move, search, or tick the clock forward. If you spin the golden Mickey Mouse ear, it’s time to search! Flip over a Search Card and everyone starts looking for the item on the card. For each item a player finds that is one step forward for all players. If all players arrive at the castle before the clock strikes midnight everyone wins!

Changes from Richard Scarry's Busytown: Eye found it! Game:

- Different board configurations. The movement track in the Disney game is noticeably longer and more complex (there are 2-3x more spaces on the board in the Disney version).

- The spinner wheel for Busytown is numbered 1-4, so a player moves at most 4 spaces on his/her turn. For the Disney version, the spinner is numbered 1-8.

- Different player count. Busytown is for 2-4 players; Disney is for 1-6 players.

- Busytown has a built in timer. There are food pieces that the pigs are eating. The players must all get to the ferry, which leaves when they all arrive. Then, they go the the picnic island. The more food left, the higher the score. In the Disney version, all the players win or lose.

item.description:
Based upon a popular youth fiction book.

Be part of the story, work alone or co-operate with your team and build the time machine!
At the start of the game, every player gets a secret role card, which determines the team the player is part of. During the game, the players have to deduce who their partners and who their opponents are. The goal is to find as many parts of the time machine as possible. It's not enough to find the parts though, the teams have to defend their findings as well, because it's possible to steal items from other players.

During the game, players use their action cards to move the characters on the board. These cards have different possible actions based upon the location of the moved character on the board. These characters can find and pick up parts of the time machine, and the player who moved the given character gets the part, which is essential for winning the game.

item.description:
Micropolis is a family city-building game with a modular board.

On your turn, roll two 10-sided dice, then select actions to perform using the numbers you rolled.

 Acquire Property — Place a roof token on a city block bearing the rolled number. (Once you have two roof tokens on a city block, no one else can build on it any longer.) You can use 0 as a wild to place on any number, and doubles grant you a free bonus action of placing a single roof on any city block where you already have a roof.
 Construct Buildings — Remove roof tokens from the footprint of the building specified on the contract card (you must have sole or shared control of each city block in question), and then place the appropriate building pieces as depicted on the contract card. Bonuses and penalties specified on the card for positioning relative to other features apply.
 Build Monorail Line — Start the monorail line between city blocks, or extend the existing line, if it has already been started.
 Acquire a City Tile from the deck.
 Place a City Tile adjacent to existing tiles.
 Reroll
 Exchange Contract Cards




Once both Contract decks are depleted, the endgame is triggered, giving each player one more turn. The player who has accumulated the most points wins.

How Good Is Your Karma? ...You'll know after playing this!!
 
Unpredictable and designed to be smoker-friendly, it's a great way to spend a stretchable hour or so with like minded friends. Not sneaky, not dishonest but likely to provoke profanity!
 
Chill with friends and visit Morrocco, Marrakesh and Amsterdam to try and score. Then, if you manage that, run the gauntlet of customs, police and your own Karma to get rid of it. The winner leaves loaded and holding, the losers just have some fun.

Originally created by stoner students in a UK university in the 1970's, the legendary Big Dope Deal board game is now available for anyone to play! Travel to London, Amsterdam, Marrakesh, and Kabul and score weed along the way, with all the board game fun of dice, fake paper money and full-color cards. Big Dope Deal is ideal for 2 to 6 adult players and an average game takes about one high-stakes, hilarious hour. The 15 x 12.8 inch board is flexible and rolls up easily, and it's laminated so don't worry if you spill some beer on it.

Frogs are very hungry, and a whole menu of insects is within reach. With Frog Menu, you should eat as many insects as possible, and to do this you must jump from insect to insect, eating non-stop. Be sure not to get isolated while doing so!

To start, shuffle 2-4 starting tiles with a bunch of insect tiles, then lay out the tiles face up in a 6x6, 7x7, or 8x8 square (based on the number of players). Each player starts with two random power tiles (fish, egg, tongue), with each type of tile having a different special action. Each player starts on the board wherever their starting tile turns up.

On a turn, the active player jumps their frog based on the possible move shown on the tile where that frog is currently located; the player can rotate the tile to use the move in one of four directions, claiming this tile and removing it from the board. As tiles are removed, the board gets holes in it, and players can jump their frogs over these holes. Once a frog is isolated, that player takes no further turns. Once every frog is isolated, players claim the tile under their frog, then tally their points.

Players score based on the types and quantities of insects they've collected, with the game including seven types of insects. A player's starting tile counts as an insect of their choice. The scores for the different groupings of insects are:


 5 insects of the same species, 50.
 5 different insects, 40.
 4 insects of the same species, 30.
 3 insects of the same species + 2 insects of the same species, 20.
 3 insects of the same species, 10.
 2 insects of the same species, 5.


Whoever has the most points wins, with ties being broken by whoever has the combination of insects with the most value.
